page.title: Honor system at the University of Virginia

revision.text:
'''HONOR PLEDGE'''
On my honor as a student, I have neither given nor received aid on this assignment/examination.
{{Main article|University of Virginia}} The [[University of Virginia]] has an honor code, formally known as the Honor System.{{cite web | title = The Honor Committee | publisher = University of Virginia | url = http://www.virginia.edu/honor/ | date = 2006-12-11 | accessdate = 2007-01-09 }} The [[Honor code|Honor System]] is intended to be student administered. It was founded by Virginia students in 1842 after John A. G. Davis, chairman of the faculty and professor of law, who was attempting to resolve a conflict between students, was shot to death.{{cite book |last=Dabney |first=Virginius |authorlink=Virginius Dabney |url=http://xtf.lib.virginia.edu/xtf/view?docId=2006_01/uvaBook/tei/b000325415.xml&chunk.id=d12&toc.id=d12&brand=default |title=Mr. Jefferson's University: A History |location=[[Charlottesville]] |publisher=[[University of Virginia Press]] |year=1981 |isbn=0-8139-0904-X |pages=9–10}} The University had at that point a 17-year history of ongoing tensions between students and faculty over strictly enforced discipline, hours, and dress. Students, sons of the most prominent families of Virginia, found particularly galling the impugning of their honor by stringent supervision during tests: "[t]he students were allowed to bring only a pencil to the classroom, they were forbidden to speak, and the professors, operating in shifts, watched them with 'lynx-like' eyes during the course of the examinations."{{cite web|url=http://richmondthenandnow.com/Newspaper-Articles/Honor-System.html |title=I Certify On My Honor--'The Real Story of How the Famed 'Honor System' at University of Virginia Functions and What Matriculating Students Should Know About It |newspaper=Richmond Times Dispatch |date=November 26, 1936 |author=C. Alphonso Smith |accessdate=February 19, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725221314/http://richmondthenandnow.com/Newspaper-Articles/Honor-System.html |archivedate=July 25, 2013 |df= }} Law professor [[Henry St. George Tucker, Sr.]], proposed a basic honor pledge as an alternative to faculty oversight.[http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=T000398 TUCKER, Henry St. George – Biographical Information] Originally the honor system only applied to allegations of cheating, although it was subsequently expanded to hold students to a general standard of gentlemanly conduct: the shared values of an all white, all male Southern aristocratic tradition.{{cite news |author= Noel C. Paul |coauthors=|title=Honoring the Code |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2002/0604/p11s02-lehl.html |quote= |work=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |date=June 4, 2002 |accessdate=2014-11-13 }} In modern times, however, the Honor System is composed of only three simple tenets: a student will not [[lie]], [[cheating|cheat]], or [[theft|steal]]. It extends to matters academic and personal, and the sole sanction for a confirmed Honor System violation is dismissal from the university. This is called the "single sanction system". [[File:Honorsystematuva.jpg|thumb|left|A plaque regarding 150 years of the Honor System, placed on the Lawn in 1992]] The system is not without its detractors—it has been criticized because the required severe penalty may prevent more moderate violations from being reported or acted upon.{{cite news|title=Professors Tepid about the Honor System |work=[[Charlottesville Daily Progress]] |url=http://www.dailyprogress.com/cdp/news/local/article/survey_uva_faculty_tepid_about_honor_system/13683/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120723223505/http://www.dailyprogress.com/cdp/news/local/article/survey_uva_faculty_tepid_about_honor_system/13683/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-23 |last=Kessler |first=Aaron |date=2006-12-27 |accessdate=2007-04-21 }} Although students have voted on numerous proposals to weaken or eliminate the single sanction over the past few decades, none has ever succeeded. Support for the honor system has waned in recent years, and in the Spring of 2007 a non-binding referendum to replace the single sanction with a tiered, multiple sanction system received 49.5% of the votes cast, falling just 62 votes shy of a majority.{{cite news|title=Students decide on referenda |work=[[Cavalier Daily]] |last=Madrecki |first=Thomas |url=http://www.cavalierdaily.com/news/2007/mar/01/students-decide-on-referenda/ |date=2007-03-01 |accessdate=2008-08-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114115956/http://www.cavalierdaily.com/news/2007/mar/01/students-decide-on-referenda/ |archivedate=2009-01-14 |df= }} While cheating convictions are relatively rare (24 students were dismissed during the 2003 academic year, and 21 more were dismissed in 2004), a large cheating scandal occurred in 2001.{{cite news |author=Greta von Susteren |coauthors= |title=University of Virginia Tackles Cheating Head On|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0105/10/bp.00.html |quote= |work=[[CNN]] |date=May 10, 2001 |accessdate=2014-11-13 }} Physics professor and Hereford College Dean Louis Bloomfield, based on a student's complaint, suspected that some of his students copied portions of their term papers from [[Fraternities and sororities|fraternity]] archives in his Introduction to Physics class. After devising a computer program to detect copied phrases of at least six sequential words, over 150 students were accused of plagiarizing or allowing others to plagiarize their work over the previous five semesters. Although over 100 of these students were eventually exonerated, 48 students either admitted guilt or were convicted, and were therefore dismissed from the university. Three of these students had already graduated, and their degrees were subsequently revoked.{{cite web |url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/2012/9/4/other-academic-integrity-cases/ |title= Past Cases May Shed Light on 'Introduction to Congress" Investigation | date=September 4, 2012 | publisher = ''[[Harvard Crimson]]'' | accessdate=August 30, 2014}} Lawsuits have challenged the honor system, such as a 1983 case brought by an expelled law student that reached the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit| Fourth Circuit Court of Appeals]]. Courts so far have concluded the system affords due process sufficient to satisfy constitutional expectations.{{cite news |author=Meg Scheu|coauthors= |title=Judge Denies Call to Dismiss Lawsuit|url=http://www.cavalierdaily.com/article/1999/07/judge-denies-call-to-dismiss-lawsuit |quote= |work=[[Cavalier Daily]] |date=June 22, 1999 |accessdate=2014-11-13}}In 1983 the Fourth Circuit rejected a challenge brought by an expelled law student, the [http://openjurist.org/719/f2d/69/henson-v-honor-committee-of-u-va-u Henson case], concluding UVA's student-run honor system afforded sufficient due process to pass constitutional scrutiny. However, there has been at least one case of UVA administration interference in an honor proceeding under the threat of a lawsuit.{{cite news |author= Robert O' Harrow Jr.|coauthors= |title=Honor Case Causes Uproar at U-Va.; Some Angry Over Official Intervention, Student Panel's Unusual Reversal of Decision |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-905552.html |quote= |work=[[Washington Post]] |date=August 8, 1994 |accessdate=2014-11-13 }} In 1993 an Honor Trial convicted Christopher Leggett of cheating. The Honor Committee of that year insisted Leggett had received a fair trial but President [[John T. Casteen III|John Casteen]] called it [http://www.virginia.edu/insideuva/textonlyarchive/94-09-09/1.txt flawed], after Leggett's family hired [[law firm]] [[Williams & Connolly]]. The President and Board of Visitors forced the Executive Committee of the Honor Committee to grant a new trial (not provided for in the Honor bylaws) and in the second trial the student jury acquitted Leggett.{{cite news |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/72266219.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Aug+10%2C+1994&author=Robert+O%27Harrow+Jr.&desc=U-Va.+Accused+of+Applying+Pressure%2C+Paying+Student%27s+Legal+Fees+in+Cheating+Case |title= U-Va. Accused of Applying Pressure, Paying Student's Legal Fees in Cheating Case|author=O'Harrow, Robert, Jr.|date=August 10, 1994 |work=archived newspaper article |publisher=Washington Post |accessdate=3 November 2012}}{{cite news |author=Helen Wu |coauthors= |title=Leggett Crops Up in New Honor laws |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1807&dat=19960402&id=CKMcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CXAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6185,843996|quote= |work=[[Cavalier Daily]] |date=April 2, 1996 |accessdate=2014-11-13 }}{{cite web |url=http://uvamagazine.org/features/article/the_evolution_of_honor_timeline#1990 |title=The Evolution of Honor Timeline |author=Barefoot, Coy|date=Spring 2008 |work= |publisher=University of Virginia Magazine |accessdate=3 November 2012}}(noting the case "garnered a great deal of media attention and criticism among alumni and students"). One Honor Committee member resigned because of the administration's interference.{{cite web |url=http://www.opengovva.org/foi-opinions/red1 |title=''Redinger v. Casteen'', Circuit Court of the City of Richmond |author=Hughes, Melvin R., Judge |date=January 18, 1995 |work=Opinion |publisher=Virginia Coalition for Open Government |accessdate=13 November 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:University of Virginia]] [[Category:Codes of conduct]]

{{Infobox Journal | cover = [[File:Cover of Hypatia.jpeg|160px]] | discipline = [[Feminist philosophy]] | abbreviation = Hypatia | editors = [[Ann Garry]], [[Serene Khader]], [[Alison Stone]] (interim) | publisher = [[Wiley-Blackwell]] | country = | history = 1986–present | frequency = Quarterly | impact = 0.712<ref>[https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/15272001 "''Hypatia''"], Wiley Online Library.</ref> | impact-year = 2017 | website = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1527-2001 | link1 = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1527-2001/currentissue | link1-name = Online access | link2 = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1527-2001/issues | link2-name = Online archive | link3 = http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/ | link3-name = Website | ISSN = 0887-5367 | eISSN = 1527-2001 | OCLC = 243426299 | LCCN = 87655721 | JSTOR = 08875367 }} '''''Hypatia: A Journal of Feminist Philosophy''''' is a [[peer-reviewed]] [[academic journal]] published quarterly by [[Wiley-Blackwell]]. As of March 2018, the journal is led by an interim editor, [[Ann Garry]], and two interim co-editors, [[Serene Khader]] and [[Alison Stone]].<ref name=EditorialBoard/> Book reviews are published by ''Hypatia Reviews Online (HRO)''.<ref>[http://hypatiareviews.org/ ''Hypatia Reviews Online''].</ref> The journal is owned by a non-profit corporation, Hypatia, Inc.<ref name=missionandvision>{{cite web|title=Hypatia Inc|url=https://missionandvision.org/nonprofit/262868769/hypatia-inc/overview|publisher=Mission&Vision|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180310062603/https://missionandvision.org/nonprofit/262868769/hypatia-inc/overview|archivedate=10 March 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref>
The idea for the journal arose out of meetings of the [[Society for Women in Philosophy]] (SWIP) in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web | title = Hypatia: A Journal of Feminist Philosophy | url = http://pembroke-archives.squarespace.com/hypatia-a-journal-of-feminist-philosophy-1/ | publisher = [[Society for Women in Philosophy]] | access-date = 29 March 2018}}</ref><ref name=Gruen2010/> Philosopher and legal scholar [[Azizah Y. al-Hibri]] became the founding editor in 1982, when it was published as a "piggy back" issue of the ''[[Women's Studies International Forum]]''.<ref name=Hibri22Oct2009/> Named after [[Hypatia of Alexandria]], a philosopher who was murdered by a mob in [[415]] CE, it became an independent journal in 1986.<ref name=Gruen2010/>
''Hypatia'' became [[#2017 dispute|involved in a damaging dispute]] in April 2017 when its associate editors published an unauthorized apology for the journal's publication of an article on [[Transracial (identity)|transracialism]], after the author and article were criticized on [[social media]]. The episode pointed to a significant breakdown of communications within ''Hypatia''{{'}}s editorial team.<ref name=Singal2May2017/><ref name=McKenzie6May2017/><ref name=Brubaker18May2017/><ref name=Schuessler19May2017/> The journal responded by setting up a task force to restructure its governance.<ref name=Weinberg13Nov2017/> ''Hypatia'' was the subject of further controversy in 2018, when it accepted a hoax article that had been deliberately designed to satirise feminist philosophy. The hoax, which formed part of the [[Grievance Studies affair|Grievance studies scandal]], was revealed before the article could be published.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/04/arts/academic-journals-hoax.html?module=inline|title=Hoaxers Slip Breastaurants and Dog-Park Sex Into Journals|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en}}</ref>
==History== {{seealso|Feminist philosophy}} ''Hypatia'' has its roots in regional meetings of the [[Society for Women in Philosophy]] (SWIP), established in 1972. One of SWIP's earliest ideas was that it would set up a philosophy journal.<ref name=Gruen2010>{{cite journal |last1=Gruen |first1=Lori |author-link1=Lori Gruen|last2=Wylie|first2=Alison |author-link2=Alison Wylie|title=Feminist Legacies/Feminist Futures: 25th Anniversary Special Issue—Editors' Introduction |journal=Hypatia |date=Fall 2010 |volume=25 |issue=4 |pages=725–732|jstor=40928652}}</ref> The thought of "[[A Room of One's Own|a journal of our own"]] was very powerful, according to Kathryn Morgan ([[University of Toronto|Toronto]]), speaking in 2009 on the history of ''Hypatia''.<ref name="Interview 00:08:45">{{cite web|title=Interview with Hypatia Founders and Editors|url=https://vimeo.com/13360820|publisher=25th Anniversary Conference: Feminist Legacies/Feminist Futures, University of Washington|date=24 October 2009|at=From 00:08:45|ref={{sfnref|25th Anniversary Conference|2009}}}}</ref> At the time, according to [[Linda Martín Alcoff]] ([[City University of New York|CUNY]]), president of the Hypatia Inc. board of directors since February 2018,<ref name=search23Feb2018/> philosophers who wanted to write about gender-related issues were being silenced in a discipline "riven by unabashed bias and vested interest, inflicting its own form of unapologetic mob violence".<ref name=Alcoff4May2017/>
[[File:Azizah Y. al-Hibri, 2012.jpeg|thumb|left|upright=0.8|[[Azizah Y. al-Hibri]], 2012]] SWIP decided in 1977 to set up an [[editorial board]] to plan the journal; the first board was put together by [[Ann Garry]] ([[California State University, Los Angeles|Cal State LA]]) and Jacqueline Thomason ([[University of Massachusetts Amherst|UMass Amherst]]).<ref name=Gruen2010/>{{efn|The 1977 SWIP editorial board included [[Ann Garry]], Jacqueline Thomason, [[Sandra Bartky]], Candace Groudine, [[Sandra Harding]], [[Sarah Hoagland]], [[Alison Jaggar]], [[Helen Longino]], [[Linda López McAlister]], [[Kathryn Morgan]], Janice Moulton, Connie Crank Price, and Joyce Trebilco.<ref name=Gruen2010/>}} At a meeting in Denver in the spring of 1979, the board agreed that [[Azizah Y. al-Hibri]] ([[University of Richmond|UR]]) should be the founding editor.<ref name=Gruen2010/> Al-Hibri began work on the journal in 1982, after she had completed her PhD in philosophy and just as she was starting her first year of [[law school]].<ref name=Hibri22Oct2009>{{cite news|last1=Al-Hibri|first1=Azizah Y|author-link=Azizah Y. al-Hibri|title=A Journal of Her Own: Hypatia Founders and Editors|url=https://vimeo.com/12221774|publisher=25th Anniversary Conference: Feminist Legacies/Feminist Futures, University of Washington|date=22 October 2009|at=Courtesy of Vimeo, 00:05:50–00:08:15|ref=harv}}</ref> The philosophy and women's studies departments at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] offered support in the form of an office and research assistance.{{sfn|Al-Hibri|2009|loc=from 00:08:57}} ''[[Women's Studies International Forum]]'' agreed to publish the new journal as an annual "piggy back" issue of its own, which it did for three years,<ref name=Hibri22Oct2009/> and distributed 10,000 brochures to its mailing list advertising it.{{sfn|25th Anniversary Conference|2009|loc=from 00:08:45}}
The group led by Al-Hibri decided that submissions would be fully reviewed and that substantive comments would be offered, Alcoff wrote, rather than the usual brief rejection, to help authors improve their work and to contribute to the field's development.<ref name=Alcoff4May2017>{{cite web|last1=Alcoff|first1=Linda Martín|author-link=Linda Martín Alcoff|title=Here's my take.|url=https://www.facebook.com/lsalcoff/posts/10156108465053047|publisher=Facebook|archiveurl=https://archive.is/PYN7m|archivedate=15 May 2017|date=4 May 2017|dead-url=no}}</ref> Donna Serniak ([[University of Pennsylvania|Penn]]) was responsible for the first issue.{{sfn|Al-Hibri|2009|loc=from 00:11:30}} It was first published independently of ''Women's Studies International Forum'' in 1986.<ref name=Gruen2010/>
The journal is named after [[Hypatia of Alexandria]], a mathematician and philosopher who was murdered by a mob in 415 CE. Al-Hibri said that the SWIP editorial board chose the name to reflect that women have "deep roots in philosophy".{{sfn|Al-Hibri|2009|loc=from 00:08:57}} According to [[Linda López McAlister]] ([[University of South Florida|USF]]), the idea for the name came from Sue Larson ([[Barnard College|Barnard]]) during a meeting of Eastern SWIP in 1973. [[Sandra Harding]] ([[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]]), who was at the meeting, objected, thinking it awful to name a feminist-philosophy journal after a woman who had been "stoned to death for telling the truth".{{sfn|25th Anniversary Conference|2009|loc=00:02:50}} The first suggestion was ''Hypatia: A Journal of Philosophy and Feminism'', rather than ''A Journal of Feminist Philosophy'', because at the time it was unclear what feminist philosophy might be.{{sfn|25th Anniversary Conference|2009|loc=from 00:05:45}}
==Governance== ''Hypatia'' is owned by a non-profit corporation, Hypatia, Inc., registered in April 2008 in the State of Washington.<ref name=missionandvision/><ref name=McKenzie6May2017/><ref name=governance>{{cite web|title=''Hypatia'' governance, adopted 26 June 2009 by the Hypatia editors and associate editors|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/pdfs/hypatia_governance.pdf|publisher=''Hypatia''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201043324/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/pdfs/hypatia_governance.pdf|archivedate=1 December 2017|dead-url=yes}}</ref> The purpose of the non-profit is "to foster feminist scholarship in philosophy and related fields, including through the publication of the academic journal ''Hypatia''".<ref name=governance/> As of 18 February 2018, the board of directors consists of Linda Martín Alcoff (CUNY), Talia Mae Bettcher (Cal State LA), [[Helen Longino]] ([[Stanford University|Stanford]]), Jacqueline Scott ([[Loyola University Chicago|Loyola]]), and [[Nancy Tuana]] ([[Pennsylvania State University|Penn State]]). [[Ann Garry]] (Cal State LA) serves ''[[ex officio]]'' as the editorial-team representative.<ref name=taskforce/> There is also an advisory board, an editorial board, and a governance task force.<ref name=edandgov>{{cite web |title=Editorial and governance boards |url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/about/edandgovboards/ |website=Hypatia |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180724092156/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/about/edandgovboards/ |archivedate=24 July 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref>
Editors-in-chief usually serve five-year terms. As of March 2018, the journal is led by an interim editor, Ann Garry, and two interim co-editors, [[Serene Khader]] ([[Brooklyn College]]/CUNY) and [[Alison Stone]] ([[Lancaster University|Lancaster]]). The interim editors of ''Hypatia Reviews Online'' are Simon Ruchti and Joan Woolfrey (both [[West Chester University|WCUPA]]).<ref name=EditorialBoard>{{cite web|title=Editorial board|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/about/editorialboard/|publisher=''Hypatia''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301224919/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/about/editorialboard/|archivedate=1 March 2018|date=1 March 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref> Previous editors-in-chief were:<ref name=EditorialBoard>{{cite web|title=Editorial board|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/about/editorialboard/|publisher=''Hypatia''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301224919/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/about/editorialboard/|archivedate=1 March 2018|date=1 March 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref>
{{columns-list|colwidth=26em| * [[Azizah al-Hibri]] (1982–1984)<ref name=HonorRoll>{{cite web|title=Hypatia Honor Roll|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/honor_roll_2013.html|publisher=''Hypatia''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170808112927/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/honor_roll_2013.html|archivedate=8 August 2017|dead-url=yes}}</ref> * Margaret Simons (1984–1990) * [[Linda López McAlister]] (1990–1998), with Cheryl Hall and Joanne Waugh (1995–1998) * [[Laurie Shrage|Laurie J. Shrage]] and [[Nancy Tuana]] (1998–2003) * [[Hilde Lindemann]] (2003–2008) * [[Lori Gruen]] (2008–2010) and [[Alison Wylie]] (2008–2013) * [[Linda Martín Alcoff]] and [[Ann Cudd]] (2010–2013) * [[Sally Scholz]] (2013–2017) }}
==Readers== ''Hypatia'' has an international readership. According to the publisher, 48 percent of its 373,011 full-text downloads went to subscribers outside North America in 2016. Around 10,500 unique visitors were registered every month by [[Wiley-Blackwell]]'s ''Hypatia'' website as of that year. Around the world, 4,048 libraries provided access to the journal through subscriptions, and another 6,943 in the developing world were able to access it at little or no cost.<ref name=stats>{{cite web |title=Hypatia statistics |url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/about/hypatia-statistics/ |website=Hypatia |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180724103830/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/about/hypatia-statistics/ |archivedate=24 July 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref>
==2017 dispute{{anchor|2017 dispute}}== === Transracialism article === {{main|Hypatia transracialism controversy}} ''Hypatia'' became involved in a dispute in April 2017 that led to the [[online shaming]] of one of its authors, Rebecca Tuvel, an [[Academic tenure|untenured]] [[assistant professor]] of philosophy at [[Rhodes College]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]].<ref name=Singal2May2017>{{Cite news|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2017/05/transracialism-article-controversy.html|title=This Is What a Modern-Day Witch Hunt Looks Like|date=2 May 2017|work=New York Magazine|author=Jesse Singal}}</ref><ref name=Weinberg1May2017>{{cite news|last1=Weinberg|first1=Justin|title=Philosopher’s Article On Transracialism Sparks Controversy (Updated with response from author)|url=http://dailynous.com/2017/05/01/philosophers-article-transracialism-sparks-controversy/|work=Daily Nous|date=1 May 2017}}</ref> The episode pointed to a breakdown of communications within ''Hypatia''{{'}}s editorial team, and to a rift within [[feminism]] and academic [[philosophy]].<ref name=McKenzie6May2017>{{cite news|last1=McKenzie|first1=Lindsay|last2=Harris|first2=Adam|last3=Zamudio-Suaréz|first3=Fernanda|title=A Journal Article Provoked a Schism in Philosophy. Now the Rifts Are Deepening|url=http://www.chronicle.com/article/A-Journal-Article-Provoked-a/240021|work=The Chronicle of Higher Education|date=6 May 2017}}</ref><ref name=Brubaker18May2017>{{cite news|last1=Brubaker|first1=Rogers|author-link=Rogers Brubaker|title=The Uproar Over ‘Transracialism’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/18/opinion/the-uproar-over-transracialism.html|work=The New York Times|date=18 May 2017}}</ref><ref name=Schuessler19May2017>{{cite news|last1=Schuessler|first1=Jennifer|title=A Defense of ‘Transracial’ Identity Roils Philosophy World|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/19/arts/a-defense-of-transracial-identity-roils-philosophy-world.html|work=The New York Times|date=19 May 2017}}</ref>
The journal had published Tuvel's article, "In Defense of Transracialism", in its spring 2017 edition after the standard double-anonymous [[Scholarly peer review|peer review]]. Comparing the case of [[Caitlyn Jenner]] to that of [[Rachel Dolezal]], Tuvel argued that "[s]ince we should accept transgender individuals' decisions to change sexes, we should also accept transracial individuals' decisions to change races."<ref name=Tuvel2017>{{cite journal|last1=Tuvel|first1=Rebecca|title=In Defense of Transracialism|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/hypa.12327/full|journal=Hypatia|date=25 April 2017|volume=32|issue=2|pages=263–278|doi=10.1111/hypa.12327|archive-url=https://archive.is/bi8Zz|archive-date=12 May 2017|dead-url=yes|ref=harv}}</ref> On 28 April the article was criticized on [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]], and Tuvel became the target of personal attacks.<ref name=Oliver7May2017>{{cite news|last1=Oliver|first1=Kelly|author-link=Kelly Oliver|title=If this is feminism|url=http://thephilosophicalsalon.com/if-this-is-feminism-its-been-hijacked-by-the-thought-police/|work=The Philosophical Salon|publisher=Los Angeles Review of Books|date=7 May 2017}}</ref><ref name=Sosis>Sosis, Cliff (5 October 2017). [http://www.whatisitliketobeaphilosopher.com/rebecca-tuvel/ "Interview with Rebecca Tuvel"], ''What Is It Like to Be a Philosopher?''.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Tuvel|first=Rebecca|date=Winter 2018|url=https://www.pdcnet.org/C1257B82005A7B6C/file/A70140B8B305A70B8525826B006A6E2D/$FILE/philtoday_2018_0062_0001_0077_0092.pdf|title=Racial Transitions and Controversial Positions: Reply to Taylor, Gordon, Sealey, Hom, and Botts|work=Philosophy Today|volume=62|issue=1|pages=(73–88), 74|format=pdf|doi=10.5840/philtoday2018223200}}</ref> The following day an [[open letter]], listing a member of ''Hypatia''{{'}}s editorial board as its point of contact, urged that the article be retracted;<ref name=Singal2May2017/><ref name=letter>{{cite news |title=Open letter to Hypatia |url=https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1efp9C0MHch_6Kfgtlm0PZ76nirWtcEsqWHcvgidl2mU/viewform?ts=59066d20&edit_requested=true |publisher=Google Docs |archiveurl=https://archive.is/lUeR4 |archivedate=2 May 2017}}</ref> by 2 May this had gathered 830 signatures.<ref name=Anderson18May2017>{{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Elizabeth|last2=Francis|first2=Leslie (Treasurer)|last3=Grasswick|first3=Heidi (Secretary)|last4=Solomon|first4=Miriam (President)|last5=Tessman|first5=Lisa (Chair)|title=Statement From Hypatia Board|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/index.html|publisher=''Hypatia''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170609221247/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/index.html|archivedate=9 June 2017|date=18 May 2017}}</ref> The journal distanced itself further from the article on 1 May when an ''Hypatia'' associate editor apologized on the journal's Facebook page for the article's publication, on behalf of "a majority of the Hypatia's Board of Associated Editors".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Heyes|first1=Cressida|title=To our friends and colleagues in feminist philosophy|url=https://www.facebook.com/hypatia.editorialoffice/posts/1852550825032876|publisher=''Hypatia''{{'}}s Facebook page|archiveurl=https://archive.is/AuDu8|archivedate=1 May 2017|date=1 May 2017|dead-url=yes}}</ref><ref name=McKenzie1May2017>McKenzie, Lindsay (1 May 2017). [http://www.chronicle.com/blogs/ticker/journal-apologizes-for-article-likening-transracialism-to-transgenderism/118084 "Journal Apologizes for Article Likening Transracialism to Being Transgender"]. ''Chronicle of Higher Education''.</ref>{{efn|At the time of the dispute in April–May 2017, the 10 associate editors were [[Linda Martín Alcoff]] (CUNY),<ref name=Alcoff4May2017/> Ann Cahill ([[Elon University|Elon]]); Kim Hall ([[Appalachian State University|Appalachian]]); [[Cressida Heyes]] ([[University of Alberta|Alberta]]); Karen Jones ([[University of Melbourne|Melbourne]]); Kyoo Lee ([[John Jay College of Criminal Justice|John Jay]]); Mariana Ortega ([[John Carroll University|John Carroll]]); [[Ásta Kristjana Sveinsdóttir]] ([[San Francisco State University|SFSU]]); [[Alison Wylie]] ([[University of Washington|Washington]]); and [[George Yancy]] ([[Emory University|Emory]]).<ref name=boardMay2017>{{cite web|title=Hypatia Editorial Board|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/editors.html|publisher=''Hypatia''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170606005257/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/editors.html|archivedate=6 June 2017|dead-url=yes}}</ref>}} The editor-in-chief, Sally Scholz (Villanova), stood by the article, and the board of directors, led by [[Miriam Solomon]] ([[Temple University|Temple]]), confirmed that it would not be retracted.<ref name=McKenzie6May2017/>
===Task force=== In July 2017 Scholz resigned as editor-in-chief, along with Shelley Wilcox, editor of ''Hypatia Reviews Online''. The board of directors announced that a task force would restructure the journal's governance, and that anyone in an editorial or non-board position with ''Hypatia'' would be "required to sign a statement of adherence to guidelines issued by COPE, the [[Committee on Publication Ethics]]".<ref name=resignation>{{cite web |title=Board of Directors' Statement (July 20, 2017) |url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/statements/board-directors-statement-july-20-2017/ |website=Hypatia |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180724105806/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/statements/board-directors-statement-july-20-2017/ |date=20 July 2017|archivedate=24 July 2018}}</ref><ref name=interim>{{cite web|title=Continuation of Interim Editorial Team|url=http://www.hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/index.html|publisher=Hypatia News|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171201043838/http://www.hypatiaphilosophy.org/Editorial/index.html|date=20 July 2017|archivedate=1 December 2017|dead-url=yes}}</ref><ref name=Weinberg3Aug2017>{{cite news|last1=Weinberg|first1=Justin|title=Further Developments at Hypatia|url=http://dailynous.com/2017/08/03/further-developments-at-hypatia/|work=Daily Nous|date=3 August 2017}}</ref> According to a statement from the associate editors, whose role was to choose the next editor, the board of directors asked them, on 17 July, to resign or the journal's governance documents would be suspended, which would remove the associate editors' influence. Eight of the associate editors resigned. In their resignation statement, they wrote that the current controversy was "grounded in long-standing differences and tensions within the field." They argued that feminist philosophy had an ethical commitment to transform philosophy into "a discipline that honors the perspectives and welcomes the scholarly contributions of historically marginalized groups, including people of color, trans* people, disabled people, and queer people."<ref name=Weinberg24July2017>{{cite news|last1=Weinberg|first1=Justin|title=Hypatia's Associate Editors Resign|url=http://dailynous.com/2017/07/24/hypatias-associate-editors-resign/|work=Daily Nous|date=24 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Flaherty|first1=Colleen|title=(Another) Shake-Up at ‘Hypatia’|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2017/07/24/divisions-within-hypatias-editorial-board-lead-resignations-top-editors|work=Inside Higher Ed|date=24 July 2017}}</ref><ref name=Zamudio-Suaréz21July2017>{{cite news|last1=Zamudio-Suaréz|first1=Fernanda|title=Months After 'Transracialism' Flap, Controversy Still Rages at Feminist Philosophy Journal|url=http://www.chronicle.com/article/Months-After/240722|work=The Chronicle of Higher Education|date=21 July 2017}}</ref>
The board appointed interim editors, and in November 2017 [[Sally Haslanger]] ([[MIT]]), Serene Khader, and Yannik Thiem (Villanova) were named as the governance task-force co-chairs.<ref name=taskforce>{{cite news|title=Hypatia Board of Directors Announces Task Force Co-Chairs|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/task-force/hypatia-board-directors-announces-task-force-co-chairs/|work=Hypatia|date=1 November 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180724115800/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/task-force/hypatia-board-directors-announces-task-force-co-chairs/|archivedate=24 July 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name=Weinberg13Nov2017>{{cite news|last1=Weinberg|first1=Justin|title=Hypatia Board Announces Task Force|url=http://dailynous.com/2017/11/13/hypatia-board-announces-task-force/|work=Daily Nous|date=13 November 2017}}</ref> The five-person board of directors, including Solomon, was replaced in February 2018.<ref name=search23Feb2018/> Linda Martín Alcoff and Kim Hall, two of the associate editors who resigned in July,<ref name=Weinberg24July2017/> became president of the board of directors and chair of the search committee for the new editorial team, respectively.<ref name=search23Feb2018>{{cite web|title=Announcement from Hypatia's Board of Directors and Task Force Co-Chairs|url=http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/announcements/announcement-hypatias-board-directors-task-force-co-chairs/|publisher=''Hypatia''|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301164503/http://hypatiaphilosophy.org/announcements/announcement-hypatias-board-directors-task-force-co-chairs/|archivedate=1 March 2018|date=23 February 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref>

'''Ionel Gherea''', also known as '''Ioan Dobrogeanu-Gherea''' or '''Ion D. Gherea''' ([[Francization|Francized]] ''J. D. Ghéréa''; 1895 – November 5, 1978), was a [[Romania]]n philosopher, essayist, and concert pianist. The son of [[Constantin Dobrogeanu-Gherea]], a [[Marxism|Marxist]] theoretician and critic, and the brother of communist militant [[Alexandru Dobrogeanu-Gherea|Alexandru "Sașa" Gherea]], he discarded their political and literary influence, being more interested in the [[aestheticism]] of his brother-in-law, [[Paul Zarifopol]]. As a youth, Zarifopol took him to meet playwright [[Ion Luca Caragiale]] and his family. Gherea's debut as a writer was a 1920 novel written jointly with [[Luca Caragiale]], which was also his only contribution to the genre.
Enjoying national success as an accompanist for [[George Enescu]], Gherea was also a respected literary essayist, and a noted Romanian [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenologist]], [[Ontology|ontologist]], and [[Aesthetics|philosopher of art]]; his lasting friendship with philosopher [[Constantin Noica]] transcended ethnic and ideological barriers. An [[Anti-authoritarianism|anti-authoritarian]], Gherea was repressed by during the first decade of [[Communist Romania|Romanian communism]], but reemerged in the 1960s as a memoirist and [[Friedrich Nietzsche|Nietzsche]] translator.
==Biography==
===Origins and early life=== Born into a [[Romanian Jews|Jewish]] family in [[Ploiești]], he was the third child of Marxist Constantin Dobrogeanu-Gherea and his wife Sofia (''née'' Parcevska, or ''Parcevskaia'').<ref name="simion">[[Eugen Simion]] (ed.), ''Dicționarul general al literaturii Române'', vol. 6, pp. 325–326. Bucharest: [[Univers Enciclopedic]], 2007. {{ISBN|973-637-070-4}}</ref> The family originated in [[Dnipropetrovsk|Yekaterinoslav]], a Ukrainian part of the [[Russian Empire]]: patriarch Gherea fled to Romania to escape persecution for his political activism, and worked menial jobs before getting his break in journalism.<ref>Atanasiu, pp. 373–377</ref> At [[Iași]], he married Sofia; she was the daughter of a Polish [[gourmet chef]], who was also Gherea's business associate.<ref>Păcurariu, pp. 42–43</ref> Around the time of Ionel's birth, his father, mother, and his grown-up siblings were managing the Ploiești Train Station Restaurant, a venue for commercial and literary transactions, but also a hangout for Romanian and exile Russian Marxists, including [[Leon Trotsky]] and [[Pavel Axelrod]].<ref>Atanasiu, pp. 57–58, 178–180; Păcurariu, ''passim''</ref> Alexandru soon made an impact as a revolutionary socialist, and later communist, militant.<ref>Beke, pp. 240–241</ref><ref name="vtstilist">{{ro icon}} [[Vladimir Tismăneanu]], [http://www.lapunkt.ro/2014/07/21/un-stilist-al-ideilor-paul-zarifopol-si-snobismul-mesianic/ "Un stilist al ideilor: Paul Zarifopol și snobismul mesianic"], in ''LaPunkt'', July 21, 2014</ref>
Gherea's early education took place at home and was followed by the local [[Ion Luca Caragiale National College (Ploiești)|Saints Peter and Paul High School]], where he graduated from the sciences section.<ref name="simion"/> Together with his elder sister Ștefania and her husband, literary critic [[Paul Zarifopol]], he lived in Germany for a time, especially in [[Leipzig]], and in Italy, but returned home upon the outbreak of World War I.<ref name="simion"/> In his father's houses in Ploiești and [[Sinaia]], as well as in Germany, he became acquainted with Caragiale; Gherea became friends with the playwright's younger son Luca (Luki). Other cultural figures whom he met in the family homes include [[Barbu Ștefănescu Delavrancea]], [[Alexandru Vlahuță]], [[George Coșbuc]], [[Panait Cerna]] and [[Sextil Pușcariu]]. His memoirs include sharply drawn portraits as well as revealing anecdotes about Caragiale and his elder son, [[Mateiu Caragiale|Mateiu]].<ref name="simion"/>
Around 1915, young Gherea was a student at the [[University of Bucharest]] Faculty of Letters, where he became close friends with poet [[Artur Enășescu]] and met [[Tudor Vianu]], his fellow critic.<ref>[[Tudor Vianu]], ''Scriitori români'', Vol. III, [[Editura Minerva]], Bucharest, 1971, p. 321. {{OCLC|7431692}}</ref> He was also close to [[Lucia Demetrius]], and, together with Zarifopol, helped her launch her career as a novelist.<ref>{{ro icon}} [[Lucia Demetrius]], [http://www.romlit.ro/memorii "Memorii"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 4/2004</ref> Together with Luki, Gherea himself wrote the novel ''Nevinovățiile viclene'' ("The Cunning Naïvetés"). A study in adolescent psychology, which has earned posthumous appreciation,<ref name="simion"/><ref name="ipnumele">{{ro icon}} [[Ioana Pârvulescu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/n_numele_fiului "În numele fiului"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 10/2001</ref> it appeared in ''[[Viața Românească]]'' in 1920. The work shocked conservative sensibilities with its supposed libertinage, and was only taken up by the literary magazine following Zarifopol's intercession.<ref name="ipnumele"/>
With Luki dying the next year, Gherea never returned to fiction writing.<ref name="ipnumele"/> He dedicated himself to philosophy and criticism, with essays which appeared in ''[[Revue philosophique de la France et de l'étranger|Revue Philosophique]]'', ''Viața Românească'' and its satellite, ''[[Adevărul Literar și Artistic]]'', ''[[Kalende]]'', later in Zarifopol's ''[[Revista Fundațiilor Regale]]'' and ''Revista de Filosofie''. Such works reveal his intellectual debt to [[Blaise Pascal]]; a generous use of irony; complex readings from [[Leo Tolstoy]] and [[Fyodor Dostoyevsky]], but also of [[Marcel Proust]], [[Paul Valéry]], [[Francis Jammes]], and [[Knut Hamsun]].<ref name="simion"/> His abstract, philosophically grounded speculations somewhat resemble Zarifopol's, but unlike his onetime mentor, he often wrote down [[Impressionist literature|impressionist]] thoughts in the manner of [[Anatole France]], one of his favorite authors, glossing over the discrepancies and limitations of the texts he discussed.<ref name="simion"/> He is especially known for his pioneering study on Proust's [[snobbery]], which appeared in the 1929 edition of ''Adevărul Literar și Artistic'', and in which he opposed Zarifopol's own Proustianism.<ref>{{ro icon}} Dana Pîrvan-Jenaru, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/Receptarea-lui-Proust-in-Romania*articleID_20269-articles_details.html "Receptarea lui Proust în România"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 436, August 2008</ref>
===Pianist-philosopher=== Gherea was also friends with violinist-composer [[George Enescu]]: in 1927 or 1928, he accompanied Enescu as a pianist on a domestic concert tour, also leaving anecdotes from that encounter.<ref name="simion"/><ref name="ștc224">Ștefan Cervatiuc, ''Istoria teatrului la Botoşani: 1838-1944. Vol 3: 1925–1944, Index'', p. 224. Botoșani: Quadrant. {{ISBN|978-606-8238-88-3}}</ref> The two reunited in 1936, when Enescu returned to the country and included Gherea on his team of touring pianists, which also included [[Dinu Lipatti]], [[Alfred Alessandrescu]], and Muza Ghermani Ciomac.<ref>Virgil Gheorghiu, "Anul muzical 1936—1937", in ''[[Revista Fundațiilor Regale]]'', Nr. 10/1937, pp. 204–205</ref> Gherea claimed that, overall, he had been Enescu's piano accompanist in as many as 300 separate performances.<ref name="ștc224"/>
During those years, Gherea was writing a lengthy treatise on the [[philosophy of self]]; titled ''Le Moi el le monde. Essai d'une cosmogonie anthropomorphique'' ("The Self and the World. An Essay in Anthropomorphic [[Cosmogony]]"), it initially appeared in 1933 in the Paris-based ''[[Revue de Métaphysique et de Morale]]''. It was published in book form in Paris and in [[Bucharest]] in 1938.<ref name="simion"/> The book was noted by reviewer Constantin Floru for its disregard toward academic terminology, basing itself on "common sense", "years-long meditation", and "the erudition of a subtle spirit".<ref>Floru, p. 685</ref> It earned Gherea the friendship and admiration of academic philosophers [[Constantin Noica]] and [[Petru Comarnescu]], who prepared the book for [[Editura Fundațiilor Regale]]. Noica referred to Gherea as an "innovative" asset in [[Romanian philosophy]], comparing him to [[Stéphane Lupasco]] and [[Piu-Șerban Coculescu|Pius Servien]].<ref>Chișu & Noica, pp. 72, 77</ref>
''Le Moi el le monde'' mapped out an independent [[Phenomenology (philosophy)|phenomenology]] and [[ontology]], imagining situations in which the "coexistence" of individual minds creates an implicit need for [[time perception]], which inevitably leads them to the [[noumenon]]—hence, "cosmogony is anthropomorphic".<ref>Floru, pp. 686–689; Pătrășcanu, pp. 92–98</ref> As read by Floru, Gherea understood these selves as [[Monad (philosophy)|monadic units]], with direct reference to [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz|Leibnitz]]'s ontological essences.<ref>Floru, pp. 688–689</ref> Gherea's "anthropomorphism" was nevertheless a critique of "naive" [[materialism]], seeking to rehabilitate [[idealism]] with input from [[particle physics]].<ref>Pătrășcanu, p. 167</ref> [[Lucrețiu Pătrășcanu]], himself a [[historical materialist]], found the work to be "original", but remained critical of Gherea's implicit [[agnosticism]] and explicit [[consequentialism]].<ref>Pătrășcanu, pp. 97–98</ref>
During the early 1930s, Gherea and Noica were involved with the ''[[Criterion (literary society)|Criterion]]'' cultural forum. He was supposed to lecture there about the phenomenology of [[Edmund Husserl]], but, being a timid man, lost his composure; he was filled in by [[Mircea Vulcănescu]], who reused his notes.<ref>Constantin Mihai, "Dinamica conferințelor Criterionului", in ''Anuarul Institutului de Cercetări Socio-umane C. S. Nicolăescu-Plopșor'', Vol. 13, 2012, p. 50</ref> He and Noica became friends, despite the latter being a right-leaning [[National conservatism|national conservative]]. Noica wrote in 1936: "One of the several things about [Gherea] that left a mark on me is that, although he lives in a leftist milieu and carries a surname dear to the Jewish and socialist circles, he has never once profited from this and has been living in want, at least not these past few years."<ref>Chișu & Noica, p. 73</ref>
===Repression and recovery=== The rise of [[Iron Guard]] fascism and antisemitism was a disappointment for Gherea, a fact documented by [[Mihail Sebastian]], a Zarifopol disciple and fellow Jewish writer.<ref>[[Mihail Sebastian]], ''Journal, 1935-1944''. London: [[Random House]], 2003, p. 135. {{ISBN|0-7126-8388-7}}</ref> However, with Vulcănescu and Noica, he remained one of the "young philosophers and disciples" who stood by [[metaphysician]] and Guard affiliate [[Nae Ionescu]], when the latter was released from a concentration camp for political prisoners.<ref>[[Mircea Eliade]], ''Autobiography, Vol. 2. 1937–1960, Exile's Odyssey'', p. 83. Chicago: [[University of Chicago Press]], 1988. {{ISBN|0-226-20411-1}}</ref> In December 1940, the Iron Guard's [[National Legionary State|National Legionary government]] ordered his father's remains to be exhumed and reburied in a Jewish-only cemetery.<ref>[[Matatias Carp]], ''Cartea neagră. Suferințele evreilor din România, 1940—1944. I. Legionarii și rebeliunea'', p. 197. Bucharest: [[Editura Socec]], 1946</ref>
After World War II and the [[King Michael's Coup|fall of fascism]], Gherea, whose brother had taken refuge to the Soviet Union and killed as a dissident during the [[Great Purge]],<ref name="vtstilist"/> was troubled by the prospects of communization. In a 1946 interview with [[Ion Biberi]], he expressed his support for a "tolerant and libertarian democracy", but believed that the future belonged to "the sort of socialism that prevents people from speaking their mind."<ref>[[Gabriel Dimisianu]], "La început, la mijloc, la sfârșit de secol", in ''[[Lettre Internationale]]'' (Romanian edition), Nr. 62, Summer 2007</ref> Gherea's final decades were lived under the [[Communist Romania|communist regime]]. Branded a "decadent" philosopher in the Marxist works of [[Constantin Ionescu Gulian]], he was marginalized together with other thinkers of his generation.<ref name="vtgulian">{{ro icon}} [[Vladimir Tismăneanu]], [http://www.romlit.ro/c._i._gulian_exterminatorul_filosofiei_romneti "C. I. Gulian, exterminatorul filosofiei românești"], in ''[[România Literară]]'', Nr. 2/2012</ref> By 1955, his father, Constantin, was being officially recovered as a precursor of [[Socialist realism in Romania|socialist realism]], the standard literary dogma,<ref>Florin Mihăilescu, ''De la proletcultism la postmodernism''. Constanța: [[Editura Pontica]], 2002, pp. 94–95. {{ISBN|973-9224-63-6}}</ref> but his works appeared only in [[Censorship in Communist Romania|censored form]].<ref>[[Monica Lovinescu]], ''Unde scurte'', p. 410. Bucharest: [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], 1990. {{ISBN|973-28-0172-7}}</ref> Gherea was mainly focused on translation work, putting out versions of Jammes, [[Thomas de Quincey]] and [[Heinrich Mann]] into Romanian, while rendering [[Ion Marin Sadoveanu]]'s ''Sfârșit de veac în București'' into French.<ref name="simion"/>
In the late 1950s, Gherea's continued visits with Noica became a subject of interest for [[Securitate]] agents, who were monitoring Noica for his former Iron Guard affiliation. Noica and many of his friends were arrested and tried in 1960, with Gherea himself interrogated.<ref>{{ro icon}} George Ardeleanu, [http://www.observatorcultural.ro/CONSTANTIN-NOICA-IN-VIZORUL-SECURITATII*articleID_13570-articles_details.html "Constantin Noica în vizorul Securității. Meditații la limba engleză (la Cîmpulung, în 1957–1958)"], in ''[[Observator Cultural]]'', Nr. 277, July 2005</ref> Later that decade, the regime introduced controlled liberalization, and Gulian was sidelined.<ref name="vtgulian"/> ''Nevinovățiile viclene'' came out in a paperback edition at [[Editura Tineretului]], 1969.<ref name="ipnumele"/> Gherea's work became more available. His essays reprinted in ''[[Manuscriptum]]'', then as the 1971 ''Eseuri'' ("Essays"), Gherea's 1938 study was only fully published in Romanian in 1984, as ''Eul și lumea''.<ref name="simion"/>
Living his final years in Bucharest, Gherea was sought after by his father's [[Hungarians in Romania|Hungarian Romanian]] biographer and translator, [[Gyula Csehi]], their interviews published in ''Igaz Szó'' on Gherea's 70th birthday. Csehi left this portrait of Gherea Jr: "His face is surprisingly like his fathers'. He is a quiet, gentle, thoughtful man, mindful of all exaggeration."<ref>Beke, p. 241</ref> Returning to philosophical work, in 1978 Gherea and Ion Herdan also published a translation from [[Friedrich Nietzsche|Nietzsche]]'s ''[[Birth of Tragedy]]'', also signaling a recovery for the German thinker.<ref>Simion Dănilă, "Die Rezeption Friedrich Nietzsches in Rumänien", in ''Nietzsche-Studien. Internationales Jahrbuch Fur Die Nietzsche-Forschung'', Vol. 34, Issue 1, p. 243</ref>

Convorbiri cu 56 de scriitori despre relațiile literare româno-maghiare''. Bucharest: [[Editura Kriterion]], 1972. {{OCLC|38751437}} *Lucian Chișu, [[Constantin Noica]], "Corespondență. [[Image:David Hume.jpg|right|thumb|[[David Hume]] raised the is–ought problem in his ''[[Treatise of Human Nature]]''.]]
The '''is–ought problem''', as articulated by the Scottish [[philosopher]] and [[historian]] [[David Hume]] (1711–76), states that many writers make claims about what ''ought'' to be, based on statements about what ''is''. Hume found that there seems to be a significant difference between [[Positive statement|positive]] statements (about what is) and prescriptive or [[normative]] statements (about what ought to be), and that it is not obvious how one can coherently move from descriptive statements to prescriptive ones. The is–ought problem is also known as '''Hume's law''', '''Hume's guillotine''' or '''fact–value gap'''.
A similar view is defended by [[G. E. Moore]]'s [[open-question argument]], intended to refute any identification of [[moral]] properties with natural [[properties]]. This so-called [[naturalistic fallacy]] stands in contrast to the views of [[ethical naturalism|ethical naturalists]].
==Overview== Hume discusses the problem in book III, part I, section I of his book, ''[[A Treatise of Human Nature]]'' (1739):
{{quote|In every system of morality, which I have hitherto met with, I have always remarked, that the author proceeds for some time in the ordinary way of reasoning, and establishes the being of a God, or makes observations concerning human affairs; when of a sudden I am surprised to find, that instead of the usual copulations of propositions, ''is'', and ''is not'', I meet with no proposition that is not connected with an ''ought'', or an ''ought not''. This change is imperceptible; but is, however, of the last consequence. For as this ''ought'', or ''ought not'', expresses some new relation or affirmation, 'tis necessary that it should be observed and explained; and at the same time that a reason should be given, for what seems altogether inconceivable, how this new relation can be a deduction from others, which are entirely different from it. But as authors do not commonly use this precaution, I shall presume to recommend it to the readers; and am persuaded, that this small attention would subvert all the vulgar systems of morality, and let us see, that the distinction of vice and virtue is not founded merely on the relations of objects, nor is perceived by reason.<ref>{{cite wikisource|chapter=Section 1|wslink=Treatise of Human Nature/Book 3: Of morals/Part 1|plaintitle=Treatise of Human Nature|last= Hume |first= David |authorlink = David Hume |year=|publisher=|page=469-470|wspage=|scan=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last = Hume |first = David |authorlink = David Hume |title = A Treatise of Human Nature |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-Sp8B0ZdyAYC&pg=PA335#v=snippet&q=%22every%20system%20of%20morality%22&f=false |accessdate=2011-12-06 |year = 1739 |publisher = John Noon |location= London |page=335}}</ref>}}<!-- Please note before you "fix" it, that the preceding is a direct quote and that the words used in the text are so abbreviated -->
[[File:NASA-Apollo8-Dec24-Earthrise.jpg|thumb|right|120px|Hume asks, given knowledge of the way the universe ''is'', in what sense can we say it ''ought to be'' different? (photograph, ''[[Earthrise]]'')]]Hume calls for caution against such inferences in the absence of any explanation of how the ought-statements follow from the is-statements. But how exactly ''can'' an "ought" be derived from an "is"? The question, prompted by Hume's small paragraph, has become one of the central questions of ethical theory, and Hume is usually assigned the position that such a derivation is impossible.<ref>{{cite book |first=Stephen |last=Priest |title=The British Empiricists |pages=177–78 |publisher=Routledge |location= |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-415-35723-4 }}</ref> This complete severing of "is" from "ought" has been given the graphic designation of ''Hume's Guillotine''.<ref name="Black1964">{{cite journal|last1=Black|first1=Max|title=The Gap Between "Is" and "Should"|journal=The Philosophical Review|volume=73|issue=2|year=1964|page=165|issn=0031-8108|doi=10.2307/2183334}}</ref>
==Implications== The apparent gap between "is" statements and "ought" statements, when combined with [[Hume's fork]], renders "ought" statements of dubious validity. Hume's fork is the idea that all items of knowledge are based either on logic and definitions, or else on observation. If the is–ought problem holds, then "ought" statements do not seem to be known in either of these two ways, and it would seem that there can be no moral knowledge. [[Moral skepticism]] and [[non-cognitivism]] work with such conclusions.
==Responses==
===Oughts and goals=== [[File:Alonzo Babers finish.JPEG|thumb|left|150px|Few debate that one ''ought'' to run quickly ''if'' one's goal is to win a race. A tougher question may be whether one "morally ought" to want to win a race in the first place.]] [[Ethical naturalists]] contend that moral truths exist, and that their truth value relates to facts about physical reality. Many modern naturalistic philosophers see no impenetrable barrier in deriving "ought" from "is", believing it can be done whenever we analyze goal-directed behavior. They suggest that a statement of the form ''"In order for agent ''A'' to achieve goal ''B'', ''A'' reasonably ought to do ''C''"'' exhibits no [[category error]] and may be factually verified or refuted. "Oughts" exist, then, in light of the existence of goals. A counterargument to this response is that it merely pushes back the 'ought' to the subjectively valued 'goal' and thus provides no fundamentally objective basis to one's goals which, consequentially, provides no basis of distinguishing moral value of fundamentally different goals. A possible basis for an objective, moral realist, morality might be an appeal to [[teleonomy]].
This is similar to work done by moral philosopher [[Alasdair MacIntyre]], who attempts to show that because ethical language developed in the West in the context of a belief in a human [[Telos (philosophy)|telos]]—an end or goal—our inherited moral language, including terms such as good and bad, have functioned, and function, to evaluate the way in which certain behaviors facilitate the achievement of that telos. In an evaluative capacity, therefore, good and bad carry moral weight without committing a category error. For instance, a pair of scissors that cannot easily cut through paper can legitimately be called bad since it cannot fulfill its purpose effectively. Likewise, if a person is understood as having a particular purpose, then behaviour can be evaluated as good or bad in reference to that purpose. In plainer words, a person is acting good when that person fulfills that person's purpose.<ref>{{cite book |last=MacIntyre |first=Alasdair |title=After Virtue: A Study in Moral Philosophy |location=Notre Dame, IN |publisher=University of Notre Dame Press |year=1981 |pages=148–50 }}</ref>
Even if the concept of an "ought" is meaningful, this need not involve morality. This is because some goals may be morally neutral, or (if they exist) against what is moral. A poisoner might realize his victim has not died and say, for example, "I ought to have used more poison," since his goal is to murder. The next challenge of a moral realist is thus to explain what is meant by a "''moral'' ought".<ref>{{cite book |authorlink=H. L. A. Hart |last=Hart |first=H. L. A. |title=The Concept of Law |year=1994 }}</ref>
===Discourse ethics=== {{Main article|Discourse ethics}} Proponents of discourse ethics argue that the very act of discourse implies certain "oughts", that is, certain [[presupposition]]s that are necessarily accepted by the participants in discourse, and can be used to further derive prescriptive statements. They therefore argue that it is incoherent to argumentatively advance an ethical position on the basis of the is–ought problem, which contradicts these implied assumptions.
====Moral oughts==== As MacIntyre explained, someone may be called a good person if people have an inherent purpose. Many ethical systems appeal to such a purpose. This is true of some forms of [[moral realism]], which states that something can be wrong, even if every thinking person ''believes'' otherwise (the idea of [[brute fact]] about morality). The ethical realist might suggest that humans were created for a purpose (e.g. to serve God), especially if they are an [[ethical non-naturalist]]. If the ethical realist is instead an [[ethical naturalist]], they may start with the fact that humans have [[evolved]] and pursue some sort of [[evolutionary ethics]] (which risks “committing” the [[moralistic fallacy]]). Not all moral systems appeal to a human telos or purpose. This is because it is not obvious that people even ''have'' any sort of natural purpose, or what [[Teleology|that purpose]] would be. Although many scientists do recognize [[teleonomy]] (a tendency in nature), few philosophers appeal to it (this time, to avoid the naturalistic fallacy).
[[File:The Posts - geograph.org.uk - 116024.jpg|thumb|Even if oughts can be understood in relation to goals or needs, the greater challenge of ethical systems remains that of defining the nature and origins of the good, and in what sense one ought to pursue it.]] Goal-dependent oughts run into problems even without an appeal to an innate human purpose. Consider cases where one has no desire to be good—whatever it is. If, for instance, a person wants to be good, and good means washing one's hands, then it seems one morally ought to wash their hands. The bigger problem in moral philosophy is what happens if someone does ''not'' want to be good, whatever its origins? Put simply, in what sense ''ought'' we to hold the goal of being good? It seems one can ask "how am I rationally required to hold 'good' as a value, or to pursue it?"<ref>These ideas are discussed extensively in {{cite book |first=Richard |last=Joyce |title=The Myth of Morality |year=2001 }}</ref>
The issue above mentioned is a result of an important [[ethical relativist]] critique. Even if "oughts" depend on goals, the ought seems to vary with the person's goal. This is the conclusion of the [[ethical subjectivist]], who says a person can only be called good according to whether they fulfill their own, ''self-assigned'' goal. Alasdair MacIntyre himself suggests that a person's purpose comes from their culture, making him a sort of ethical relativist.<ref>Discussed in {{cite book |authorlink=J. L. Mackie |first=J. L. |last=Mackie |title=Ethics: Inventing Right and Wrong |year=1997 |location= |publisher= |isbn= }}</ref> Ethical relativists acknowledge local, institutional facts about what is right, but these are facts that can still vary by society. Thus, without an objective "moral goal", a moral ought is difficult to establish. [[G. E. M. Anscombe]] was particularly critical of the word "ought" for this reason; understood as "We need such and such, and the only way to get it is this way"—a person may need something immoral, or else find that their noble need requires immoral action.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Elizabeth |last=Anscombe |year=1958 |title=Modern Moral Philosophy |journal=[[Philosophy (journal)|Philosophy]] |volume=33 |issue=124 |pages=1–19 |jstor=3749051 |doi=10.1017/s0031819100037943}}</ref>
If moral goals depend on private assumptions or public agreement, so may morality as a whole. For example, Canada might call it good to maximize global welfare, where a citizen, Alice, calls it good to focus on herself, and then her family, and finally her friends (with little empathy for strangers). It does not seem that Alice can be objectively or rationally bound—without regard to her personal values ''nor'' those of groups of other people—to act a certain way. In other words, we may not be able to say "You just ''should'' do this". Moreover, persuading her to help strangers would necessarily mean appealing to values she already possesses (or else we would never even have a hope of persuading her).<ref>http://jetpress.org/v21/blackford3.htm</ref> This is another interest of [[normative ethics]]—questions of [[Normative ethics#Binding force|binding forces]].
There may be responses to the above relativistic critiques. As mentioned above, ethical realists that are non-natural can appeal to God's purpose for humankind. On the other hand, naturalistic thinkers may posit that valuing people's well-being is somehow 'obviously' the purpose of ethics, or else the only relevant purpose worth talking about. This is the move made by [[natural law]], [[scientific moralist]]s and some [[utilitarians]].
===Institutional facts=== [[John Searle]] also attempts to derive "ought" from "is".<ref>{{cite journal |last=Searle |first=John R. |title=How to Derive 'Ought' From 'Is' |journal=Philosophical Review |volume=73 |year=1964 |issue=1 |pages=43–58 |jstor=2183201 }}</ref> He tries to show that the act of making a promise places one under an obligation by definition, and that such an obligation amounts to an "ought". This view is still widely debated, and to answer criticisms, Searle has further developed the concept of [[institutional fact]]s, for example, that a certain building ''is'' in fact a bank and that certain paper ''is'' in fact money, which would seem to depend upon general recognition of those institutions and their value.<ref>{{cite book |last=Searle |first=John R. |year=1995 |title=The construction of social reality |location=New York |publisher=Free Press |isbn=0-02-928045-1 }}</ref>
===Indefinables===
Indefinables are concepts so global that they cannot be defined; rather, in a sense, they themselves, and the objects to which they refer, define our reality and our ideas. Their meanings cannot be stated in a true definition, but their meanings can be referred to instead by being placed with their incomplete definitions in [[self-evident]] statements, the truth of which can be tested by whether or not it is impossible to think the opposite without a contradiction. Thus, the truth of indefinable concepts and propositions using them is entirely a matter of logic.
An example of the above is that of the concepts "finite parts" and "wholes"; they cannot be defined without reference to each other and thus with some amount of circularity, but we can make the self-evident statement that "the whole is greater than any of its parts", and thus establish a meaning particular to the two concepts.
These two notions being granted, it can be said that statements of "ought" are measured by their ''prescriptive'' truth, just as statements of "is" are measured by their ''descriptive'' truth; and the descriptive truth of an "is" judgment is defined by its correspondence to reality (actual or in the mind), while the prescriptive truth of an "ought" judgment is defined according to a more limited scope—its correspondence to right desire (conceivable in the mind and able to be found in the rational appetite, but not in the more "actual" reality of things independent of the mind or rational appetite).<ref name="prescriptive truths">see Aristotle's ''Nicomachean Ethics'' 6.2</ref>
To some, this may immediately suggest the question: "How can we know what is a right desire if it is already admitted that it is not based on the more actual reality of things independent of the mind?" The beginning of the answer is found when we consider that the concepts "good", "bad", "right" and "wrong" are indefinables. Thus, right desire cannot be defined properly, but a way to refer to its meaning ''may'' be found through a self-evident prescriptive truth.<ref name="definables">As an example of philosophical argumentation that identifies particular indefinables, we take "being" and then "good". Aristotle stated that although being is not a genus (''Posterior Analytics'' 2.7), yet of everything that is, being is predicated (''Topics'' 4.1), and that the [[Genus-differentia definition]]s, of which he was the first recorded proponent, requires that its subject be defined through its genus and a differentia. But since nothing lies outside of what is predicated of being, there is nothing which can serve as a differentia. So being is postulated to be indefinable. Later, Aquinas made an [[argument]] that stated, "Good and being are the really the same, and differ only according to reason.... [G]ood presents the aspect of desirableness, which being does not present." (''Summa Theologica'', Part I, Q. 5, Art. 1) So good is postulated to be indefinable.</ref>
That self-evident truth which the moral cognitivist claims to exist upon which all other prescriptive truths are ultimately based is: ''One ought to desire what is really good for one and nothing else.'' The terms "real good" and "right desire" cannot be defined apart from each other, and thus their definitions would contain some degree of circularity, but the stated self-evident truth indicates a meaning particular to the ideas sought to be understood, and it is (the moral cognitivist might claim) impossible to think the opposite without a contradiction. Thus combined with other descriptive truths of what is good (goods in particular considered in terms of whether they suit a particular end and the limits to the possession of such particular goods being compatible with the general end of the possession of the total of all real goods throughout a whole life), a valid body of knowledge of right desire is generated.<ref name="self-evident">See for example Ruggiero, ''Thinking Critically about Ethical Issues'', 5th ed., Ch. 6.</ref>
=== Functionalist counterexamples === Several counterexamples have been offered by philosophers claiming to show that there are cases when an "ought" logically follows from an "is." First of all, [[Hilary Putnam]], by tracing back the quarrel to Hume's dictum, claims fact/value entanglement as an objection, since the distinction between them entails a value. [[Arthur Prior|A. N. Prior]] points out, from the statement "He is a sea captain," it logically follows, "He ought to do what a sea captain ought to do."<ref>[[Alasdair MacIntyre]], ''After Virtue'' (2007), p. 57</ref> [[Alasdair MacIntyre]] points out, from the statement "This watch is grossly inaccurate and irregular in time-keeping and too heavy to carry about comfortably," the evaluative conclusion validly follows, "This is a bad watch."<ref>''ibid.'', p. 57–58.</ref> John Searle points out, from the statement "Jones promised to pay Smith five dollars," it logically follows that "Jones ought to pay Smith five dollars." The act of promising by definition places the promiser under obligation.<ref>Don MacNiven, ''Creative Morality'', pp. 41–42.</ref>
=== Moral realism === [[Philippa Foot]] adopts a [[Moral realism|moral realist]] position, criticizing the idea that when evaluation is superposed on fact there has been a "committal in a new dimension."<ref>Philippa Foot, “Moral Beliefs,” ''Proceedings of the Aristotelian Society'', vol. 59 (1958), pp. 83–104.</ref> She introduces, by analogy, the practical implications of using the word "injury." Not just anything counts as an injury. There must be some impairment. When we suppose a man wants the things the injury prevents him from obtaining, haven’t we fallen into the old naturalist fallacy? {{quote|It may seem that the only way to make a necessary connection between 'injury' and the things that are to be avoided, is to say that it is only used in an 'action-guiding sense' when applied to something the speaker intends to avoid. But we should look carefully at the crucial move in that argument, and query the suggestion that someone might happen not to want anything for which he would need the use of hands or eyes. Hands and eyes, like ears and legs, play a part in so many operations that a man could only be said not to need them if he had no wants at all.<ref>''ibid''., p. 96.</ref>}} Foot argues that the virtues, like hands and eyes in the analogy, play so large a part in so many operations that it is implausible to suppose that a committal in a non-naturalist dimension is necessary to demonstrate their goodness. {{quote|Philosophers who have supposed that actual action was required if 'good' were to be used in a sincere evaluation have got into difficulties over weakness of will, and they should surely agree that enough has been done if we can show that any man has reason to aim at virtue and avoid vice. But is this impossibly difficult if we consider the kinds of things that count as virtue and vice? Consider, for instance, the cardinal virtues, prudence, temperance, courage and justice. Obviously any man needs prudence, but does he not also need to resist the temptation of pleasure when there is harm involved? And how could it be argued that he would never need to face what was fearful for the sake of some good? It is not obvious what someone would mean if he said that temperance or courage were not good qualities, and this not because of the 'praising' sense of these words, but because of the things that courage and temperance are.<ref>''ibid''., p. 97</ref>}}
=== Misunderstanding === [[Hilary Putnam]] argues philosophers that accept Hume's "is–ought" distinction reject his reasons in making this, and thus undermine the entire claim.<ref>Putnam, Hilary (2003). ''The Collapse of the Fact-Value Dichotomy and Other Essays'', Harvard University Press, pp.21-22.</ref>
Various scholars have also indicated that, in the very work where Hume argues for the is–ought problem, Hume himself derives an "ought" from an "is".<ref>Baier, Annette. "Hume's Own 'Ought' Conclusions," in Hume on Is and Ought</ref> Such seeming inconsistencies in Hume have led to an ongoing debate over whether Hume actually held to the is–ought problem in the first place, or whether he meant that ought inferences can be made but only with good argumentation.<ref>Pidgen, Charles. "Hume on Is and Ought"</ref>
==See also== {{Columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Anthropic principle]] * [[Appeal to nature]] * [[Best of all possible worlds]] * [[Big Book (thought experiment)]] * [[Buridan's ass]] * [[Deontic logic]] * [[Fact–value distinction]] * ''[[The Moral Landscape]]'' * [[Normative economics]] * [[Normative science]] * [[Positive economics]] * [[Proximate and ultimate causation]] * [[Science of morality]] * [[Situational ethics]] }}

==Further reading== * Hudson, William Donald, ''The Is/Ought Question. A Collection of Papers on the Central Problem in Moral Philosophy'', London: Macmillan, 1969. * Charles R. Pidgen, ''Hume on Is and Ought'', New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2010. * Gerhard Schurz, ''The Is-Ought Problem. An Investigation in Philosophical Logic'', Dordrecht: Kluwer, 1997.
==External links== * {{cite SEP |url-id=hume-moral/#io |title=Hume's Moral Philosophy: Is and Ought}} * [http://www.open.edu/openlearn/history-the-arts/culture/philosophy/the/ought-problem Is Ought Problem animation from The Open University and BBC Radio 4]
